title: Between 19 November 2021 and 31 December 2022, how many countries will sign their first Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) memorandum of understanding with the People's Republic of China (PRC)?
preds:
This could have resolved on the 9th of January
I have asked for resolution
I was only 85% for 7 or more at that point •	Central African Republic signed on 19th of November (I think this is counted)
https://www.seetao.com/details/124957.html
•	Guinea-Bissau signed on 22nd of November
https://www.silkroadbriefing.com/news/2021/11/28/guinea-bissau-joins-the-belt-and-road-initiative/#:~:text=The%20small%20West%20African%2C%20Atlantic,the%20Belt%20And%20Road%20Initiative.&text=Guinea%2DBissau%20is%20a%20member,border%20tariffs%20between%20African%20nations
•	Eritrea signed on 25th of November
https://www.silkroadbriefing.com/news/2021/11/28/eritrea-joins-the-belt-and-road-initiative/
•	Bukina faso was on the 29th of November

https://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/topics_665678/kjgzbdfyyq/202111/t20211130_10458963.html
•	Sao Tome and Principe on 9th of December
https://www.seetao.com/details/128386.html
•	Cuba on the 25th of Dec

https://news.cgtn.com/news/2022-01-12/China-Nicaragua-sign-MoU-on-Belt-and-Road-cooperation-16LHNgng9lm/index.html
•	Syria on Jan 12th just in case CAR doesn’t count
http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/20220113/819fc4163f384be6b8fdf2f4d9956a1c/c.html

I've temporarily lost interest in this question, so I'm adjusting my score to the masses to protect my score, or at least not make it suck really badly :) 
It irritates me that this is more or less where I started...I should have trusted my initial research.

Look Like there is 6 already!

I read the question wrong previously :(

Sounds like 2 weeks in and 2 countries have signed up 
Eritrea Nov 25th
Guinea-Bissau Nov 22nd https://www.silkroadbriefing.com/news/2021/11/28/guinea-bissau-joins-the-belt-and-road-initiative/#:~:text=The%20small%20West%20African%2C%20Atlantic,the%20Belt%20And%20Road%20Initiative.&text=Guinea%2DBissau%20is%20a%20member,border%20tariffs%20between%20African%20nations https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50979558/two-more-nations-sign-up-to-chinas-new-silk-road-initiative/ Neither Eritrea or Guinea-Bissau were on the Council of Foreign Relations list. So seeing as that is not even 1 month in I will increase my upper Bin probabilities as there is obviously diplomatic action underway

If we say the base rate is 139 countries over 8 years, that works out to be over 17 countries per year. However, that growth was not a straight-line growth with a very flattened curve since 2019 (https://greenfdc.org/countries-of-the-belt-and-road-initiative-bri/). 61 countries joined in 2018, 14 in 2019, and only 1 in 2020. (https://www.cfr.org/blog/countries-chinas-belt-and-road-initiative-whos-and-whos-out) As well, given the negative attention BRI received in some parts of the world, it is less likely for a country to sign a BRI MOU now or in the next year than before COVID-19 (especially with Australia cancelling their BRI deal with China earlier this year (https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20210421-australia-cancels-state-s-belt-and-road-deal-with-china). Layer on top of that the Biden announced "Build Back Better World (B3W)" program to compete with BRI, especially in Latin America (https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/10/01/china-belt-road-initiative-latin-america-united-states-g-7-build-back-better-world-investment/). So, even in a post-COVID-19 world, if we get there in 2022, there is likely to only be a few additions to BRI for China by the end of 2022. My money is on the 3 to 4 range (65%), or possibly even less in the 1 to 2 range (30%).

COVID certainly delayed a lot of international diplomacy. 2019 was the last year that diplomacy was mostly normal. In 2019, 14 countries made their first MOU with the PRC. Those 14 countries were spread over Europe, the Caribbean, Latin America, South Asia, and Sub-Saharan Africa.  What is the average participation rate? Sub-Saharan Africa, the Middle East, and North Africa have participation rates between 78% and 72%. Europe/Central Asia is at 59%.  Where will the additional members come from?  Latin American countries are the newest members of the BRI. Since 2017, Latin American participation is up from 6% to 50%. There are still 16 non-participants. If Latin America achieves the same participation levels as Africa and the Middle East, we can expect 7 more candidates.  Chinese investment in Africa is continuing to rise https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/1758-5899.12952. African/Middle East participation is already high, but 19 unsigned opportunities remain. China's production of COVID vaccines also provides diplomatic opportunities in Africa.

The BRI forms a central component of Xi Jinping's "Major Country Diplomacy" (Chinese: 大国外交) strategy, which calls for China to assume a greater leadership role for global affairs in accordance with its rising power and status.
Xi originally announced the strategy as the "Silk Road Economic Belt" during an official visit to Kazakhstan in September 2013.
The initiative was incorporated into the Constitution of China in 2017.
The project has a target completion date of 2049.
In response the United States, Japan and Australia had formed a counter initiative, the Blue Dot Network in 2019, followed by the G7's Build Back Better World initiative in 2021. China has engaged 138 countries and 30 international organisations in the BRI.[114] Infrastructure projects include ports, railways, highways, power stations, aviation and telecommunications.[115] The flagship projects include the China–Pakistan Economic Corridor, the Boten–Vientiane railway in Laos and Khorgas land port.
India believes the "China–Pakistan Economic Corridor" (CPEC) project ignores New Delhi's essential concerns on its sovereignty and territorial integrity.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belt_and_Road_Initiative BRI participants span the globe, although significant regional variation exists: overall participation levels are highest in Central Asia and Africa, lower in Europe and Latin America, and non-existent in North America.
However, BRI participants are not all created equal.
A MoU - memorandum of understanding- is the highest level of agreement for parties to the BRI.
In contrast, cooperation agreements have more general terms and may simply express a shared intent to collaborate in the context of the BRI. As of January 2020, 57 countries have not joined the BRI.
https://i2.wp.com/www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/FP_20201105_bri_participation-e1604591362501.jpg # ========================
What are the attributes of countries that join the BRI through cooperation agreements versus MoUs — and those that eschew it entirely?
- Non-BRI participant countries are most likely to be in Europe, North America, or Latin America and the Caribbean. They have the highest percentage of collective defense agreements with the United States and are the most democratic, most politically stable, and most economically developed. - Of the countries that have signed a cooperation agreement with China to participate in the BRI, fully half are in sub-Saharan Africa. These states have the fewest collective defense agreements with the United States and are the least democratic, least politically stable, and least economically developed. - Countries that have inked MoUs to join the BRI are the largest group. Covid19 and the financial pressure it has put on various countries, as well as associated supply chain issues puts the BRI in lower priority level both for China as well as for other countries that may be inclined to sign a MoU.
A bridge too far for China to connect, defend, and sponsor the project.
Greater awareness of potential debt trap for smaller countries.  Also less positive view politically.

Not that many countries with the autonomy to sign left on the list, or with the economic interests aligned to do so. However, a few heavies like Brasil or Argentina may feel inclined, and several small caribbean, central american or pacific countries could also be enticed and correspond with China´s maritime goals. However, political alignment and conflict such as Australia´s exit will count more and leads me towards the low end.
There are enough countries, like Pakistan and Sri Lanka, that will feel the need to join the BRI, or feel compelled to...

Wrote a nice long rational about timing, no of countries left to go, who definitely wouldn't etc. But lost it.
So you are stuck with this one. 
Gonna check which of the remaining 60ish countries in the world are likely to sign a deal.
Seems pretty common to me
